column1: #Text=Figurines stolen from Tomb of Empress Dou returned to China by Sotheby ’ s in 2003 .

#Text=In April 2001 , two people from Baqiao District , Xi ’ an Prefecture employed five farmers to break into the tomb of the Western Han Empress Dou , which is located in the eastern suburbs of the city of Xi ’ an , itself in Shaanxi Province .

#Text=They blasted their way into the tomb with dynamite and then resorted to shovels , but the noise attracted the attention of the local police , who arrived and arrested three people , with the rest escaping .

#Text=The 35-metres-deep shaft leading to the tomb was not filled in , however , and in October 2001 another gang visited the tomb , this one from Qishan County , Baoji Prefecture in Shaanxi Province .
#Text=On their first visit , the members of this gang took away four grey ceramic figurines , which they later sold for a reported 4,600 yuan each .
#Text=Over the next few days , they stole a further 200 ceramic figurines , which netted them approximately 4600 yuan .
#Text=During a later visit in December 2001 , the same gang stole 71 colour painted figurines .
#Text=By February 2002 , however , police had made several more arrests , and disrupted the Qishan and other gangs working at the tomb .
#Text=The police discovered that some figurines had been transported to Hong Kong hidden inside a truckload of new pottery , while others were recovered in Guangzhou .
#Text=Many of the Hong Kong pieces were also returned to Xi ’ an .

#Text=The grey coloured figurines are unusual , and in March 2002 a Chinese police officer recognized six of them for sale as lot 32 in Sotheby ’ s New York Fine Chinese Ceramics and Works of Art catalogue .
#Text=The Chinese Embassy in Washington DC contacted staff at Sotheby ’ s , who withdrew the pieces from sale .
#Text=US Customs then arranged for their return to China in July 2003 .
